prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A student working part-time at the offices of Edgeworth and Co. Studying to be an attorney.
Character 1
Name: Samson Tangaroa
Description: My client, and a man said to be the greatest confectioner of his generation.
Character 2
Name: Artie Frost
Description: The murder victim. Found dead inside Samson Tangaroa's chocolate work.
Character 3
Name: Judy Bound
Description: Assistant to Samson Tangaroa. She's fond of the work of sculptor Paul Halique.
Character 4
Name: Tyrell Badd
Description: The detective assigned to this case. A man of few words.
Character 5
Name: Carmelo Gusto
Description: A candy-crafting confectioner who's taking part in the contest.
Character 6
Name: Delicia Scone
Description: A confectioner who will do whatever it takes to achieve her goals.
Character 7
Name: Manfred von Karma
Description: The prosecutor in charge of this case. It is said that he has never lost a trial in these past 25 years.
Character 8
Name: Laurice Deauxnim
Description: Pseudonym of Larry Butz, my friend since childhood. He fancies himself as something of an artist.
Character 9
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 10
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 11
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 12
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: The greatest prosecutor ever to prosecute... according to himself, anyway. In actual fact, his relationship with logic is tenuous at best.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. Polishing it every day has become just another part of my daily routine.
Evidence 1
Name: Seal
Description: A seal that was found near the body when it was discovered. What could the design signify?
Evidence 2
Name: Crime Scene Notes
Description: Notes about the crime scene. The police have taken custody of the body. [info] The victim's body found in Samson Tangaroa's room, inside a chocolate treasure chest. The cause of death appears to have been blood loss following blunt force trauma. [caption] The victim's body is curled inside a chest crushed by a ship post. The body is half covered by a blue sheet. There is a silver coin next to the body.
Evidence 3
Name: Mr. Tangaroa's Teapot
Description: A Paul Halique piece with Tangaroa's fingerprints on it.
Evidence 4
Name: Contest Rules
Description: A piece of paper listing the rules for the contest.
Evidence 5
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Someone left finger marks on the chocolate frame, but didn't leave any prints.
Evidence 6
Name: Mansion Key
Description: The one and only key that unlocks every door in the mansion. Tangaroa was in possession of it the entire time.
Evidence 7
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: Salt lamp found in Scone's room. Stained with the victim's blood.
Evidence 8
Name: Fake Confections
Description: Ms. Scone's so-called creations were all fake plastic models, covered in a thick layer of whipped cream.
Evidence 9
Name: Chocolates
Description: Tangaroa's favorite, handmade by Bound. Rather misshapened, and incredibly sweet.
Evidence 10
Name: Instant Camera
Description: Takes photos that develop instantly. A new film cartridge has twenty exposures, but there are only three remaining.
Evidence 11
Name: Mr. Frost's Room
Description: A photo of Frost's sculptures, taken by Judy Bound. Two photos, one from Bound and one from Detective Badd.
Evidence 12
Name: Ms. Scone's Statement
Description: Frost's sculptures were "scrumptious", except for the lyre, which was salty.
Evidence 13
Name: Semifinal Entries
Description: Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs, but tasted the same.
Evidence 14
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 15
Name: Victim's Blood
Description: Frost's blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 16
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 17
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 18
Name: IS-7 Incident Case File
Description: Documents providing an overview of the IS-7 Incident. Documents received from Fender, including his comments in red.
Evidence 19
Name: Gallery Pamphlet
Description: A pamphlet received upon entry to the gallery.
Evidence 20
Name: Winter Wing Photo
Description: Statues matching those made by the victim eighteen years ago.
Evidence 21
Name: Pisces Statue Sketch
Description: A sketch by Larry depicting the Pisces statue exactly as he saw it.
Evidence 22
Name: Used Blowtorch
Description: There are signs it was used just before the police arrived. Possibly to heat something?
Evidence 23
Name: Luminous Cloth
Description: Cloth that glows when connected to a full-spectrum light-emitting device. [caption] Looks like a blue sheet. Delicia Scone's property. One of these was lost eighteen years ago. Given to Bound by Scone. Lost eighteen years ago, only to be rediscovered floating in the fountain.
Evidence 24
Name: Poison Gas Ingredients
Description: The gas was produced when bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion were mixed together.
Evidence 25
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 26
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Finger marks left by someone in Tangaroa's room. No accompanying prints.
Evidence 27
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: A photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident. It's a salt lamp stained with Frost's blood.
Evidence 28
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 29
Name: Teapot
Description: Designed by Paul Halique. One of Judy Bound's prize possessions.
Evidence 30
Name: Ceramic Fragment
Description: Found in a puddle of tea. The design looks familiar.
Evidence 31
Name: Lift Cart
Description: Used by Frost to transport ice eighteen years ago. The top of the platform is wet.
Evidence 32
Name: Larry's Sketches
Description: Sketches depicting exactly what Larry saw.
Evidence 33
Name: Gemini Case Analysis Results
Description: Results of the analysis conducted on the melted contents of the Gemini case.
Evidence 34
Name: Chocolates
Description: Handmade by Bound. Slightly melted after being kept in her pocket.
Evidence 35
Name: Statute of Limitations
Description: A book explaining the statutes of limitations of various crimes.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: If the body had been found in a locked room... Master would've been the prime suspect.
Person: Badd
Testimony 1
Testimony: That's why Master made sure to leave the door to his own room unlocked...
Person: Badd
Testimony 2
Testimony: And to ensure that the body would be seen... Master broke the lid on the treasure chest.
Person: Badd
Testimony 3
Testimony: After the judging... everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room...
Person: Badd
Testimony 4
Testimony: That would have created the impression... that the murder had occurred... while he was away.
Person: Badd

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I've got this murder mystery to solve, and I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let's start by going through the information provided.

First, the characters involved include Samson Tangaroa, the main suspect, and Artie Frost, the victim. There's also Judy Bound, who's the assistant to Tangaroa, and Tyrell Badd, the detective assigned to the case. Other characters like Eddie Fender, Carmelo Gusto, Delicia Scone, Manfred von Karma, and Dick Gumshoe are also mentioned, but I'll focus on the primary ones related to the evidence and testimonies.

Looking at the evidences, there's a lot to unpack. The key pieces seem to be the crime scene notes, the chocolate treasure chest, the salt lamp with blood, the frame finger marks, and the missing key. The testimonies from Badd suggest that Tangaroa was setting up the scene to implicate himself, by leaving the door unlocked and the body inside a locked chest, which would make it look like a locked room murder. This would usually point to someone with access, but in this case, Tangaroa seems to have made it look like he wasn't present.

One of the key testimonies is from Badd stating that Tangaroa broke the lid on the treasure chest, which was locked. This suggests that Tangaroa had the means to access the body, but if the door was locked, it would imply that he was the one who did it. However, the evidence mentions that the body was found in a locked room, which usually points to someone with a key or someone who was let in.

But wait, the evidence also says that the mansion key was found on Tangaroa, meaning he had access. If he left the door unlocked, then the body being in the locked chest might not necessarily make it a locked room murder. Or maybe he used the key to unlock the door, then locked it again after placing the body inside the chest. That could explain how he made it look like he wasn't there.

However, the testimony says that Tangaroa broke the lid on the treasure chest, which implies that the chest was locked, and he had to force it open. But if he had the key, he could have just opened it normally. The fact that he broke it open suggests he didn't have the key, which contradicts the evidence that the mansion key was found on him.

So, the contradiction here is that the evidence states Tangaroa had the key, implying he could have opened the chest without breaking it, but the testimony says he had to break it, implying he didn't have the key. That's a clear contradiction between Evidence 6 (Mansion Key) and Testimony 2.

Another point is the salt lamp. The testimony mentions that Frost's blood was found in the fountain, not at the scene, which supports the idea that Frost was elsewhere when the murder happened, but the evidence says it was stained with the victim's blood, placing him at the scene. However, the main contradiction seems to be around the key and the chest.

So, the key pair to look at is Evidence 6 (Mansion Key) and Testimony 2. The evidence says Tangaroa had the key, allowing him to open the chest, but the testimony says he had to break it, implying he didn't have the key. This is a direct contradiction.
</think>

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me start by going through the evidence and testimonies one by one to see if anything stands out as conflicting.

First, looking at the testimonies, I see that Manfred von Karma is testifying. He mentions that Samson Tangaroa, or Master as he's called, used a rock salt lamp to kill Artie Frost. Then he deposited the murder weapon in Delicia Scone's room. That seems like a key point.

Now, looking at the evidence, I see that Evidence 27 is about a salt lamp that was stained with Frost's blood. The description says it's a photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident, which is a salt lamp. So, the salt lamp in the evidence is linked to the IS-7 case, not the current one.

But von Karma is talking about using a rock salt lamp in the current case to kill Frost. That's a bit confusing. If the salt lamp used in the current case is the same as the one from the IS-7 case, then how could it be used again? Unless it's a different one, but the evidence doesn't mention another salt lamp.

Also, von Karma says that if the murder weapon had been left at the crime scene, Master would have been suspected. But in reality, the murder weapon was moved to Delicia's room, so there was no evidence pointing to Master at the crime scene. That makes sense because moving the weapon would prevent it from being found at the scene, thus avoiding suspicion.

Wait, but the evidence says that the salt lamp was found in Scone's room, which aligns with von Karma's testimony. However, the description in Evidence 27 refers to the IS-7 case, not the current one. So, there might be a mix-up here. The current case's salt lamp isn't mentioned in the evidence, which could mean that von Karma's testimony is based on the IS-7 case, not the current one.

This contradiction arises because von Karma is connecting the current case's salt lamp to the IS-7 case, but the evidence doesn't support that the same salt lamp was used here. Therefore, the testimony might be confusing the two cases, leading to a contradiction.

Alternatively, if the salt lamp used in the current case is indeed a new one, then the evidence doesn't mention it, which could indicate that von Karma is relying on incorrect information or is mislinking evidence from previous cases.

So, putting it all together, the key contradiction is that von Karma's testimony links the current case's salt lamp to the IS-7 case, but the evidence only mentions the IS-7 salt lamp, not the current one. This suggests that von Karma might be confusing the two cases or misrepresenting the evidence.
</think>

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: That artist was the "first" to discover the victim, so naturally he's the "best" suspect!
Person: Debeste
Testimony 1
Testimony: The poison gas was caused by Normallium, a chemical found in paint, right?
Person: Debeste
Testimony 2
Testimony: As he was carrying paint near the victim, he would've had the "best" chance.
Person: Debeste
Testimony 3
Testimony: The paint, along with being the first witness! ...That pretty much proves he's the culprit!
Person: Debeste

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which piece of evidence contradicts which testimony in this case. Let me start by going through the details provided.

First, I'll look at the testimonies. There are four testimonies from Person: Debeste. Testimony 0 says, "That artist was the 'first' to discover the victim, so naturally he's the 'best' suspect!" Testimony 1 adds, "The poison gas was caused by Normallium, a chemical found in paint, right?" Testimony 2 follows up, "As he was carrying paint near the victim, he would've had the 'best' chance." Finally, Testimony 3 concludes, "The paint, along with being the first witness! ...That pretty much proves he's the culprit!"

Now, looking at the evidence, I need to find something that directly contradicts these testimonies. Evidence 24 mentions that the poison gas was produced by mixing bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion. However, Evidence 26 states that Normallium, a chemical found in paint, was the cause of the gas.

Wait, there's a conflict here. Testimony 1 says the gas was caused by Normallium, found in paint, while Evidence 24 mentions a different combination of chemicals. This seems contradictory because both can't be true if they're different causes. So, Evidence 24 contradicts Testimony 1 because they both claim to be the cause of the poison gas but using different chemicals.

Additionally, Testimony 2 and Testimony 3 also rely on the assumption that paint was the cause, which aligns with Testimony 1 but contradicts Evidence 24. Therefore, the main contradiction is between Evidence 24 and Testimony 1, with Testimony 2 and 3 supporting the same flawed assumption.

So, the evidence (Evidence 24) contradicts the testimony (Testimony 1) because they provide different causes for the poison gas, which can't both be accurate. This inconsistency suggests that either one of them is incorrect or there's a misunderstanding in the case details.
</think>
